Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Are moderate laws more effective than extreme ones in changing unfair customs?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Policy makers in many developing countries attempt to change unfair and inefficient social norms by introducing progressive laws. Sometimes these laws are ineffective in the presence of norms that conflict with these laws; other times these laws are able to change the norms by drawing them closer to the law. Understanding what makes a law effective in changing social norms is essential to crafting better laws. The development economics and legal literature hypothesize that moderate laws are more effective than radical ones in initiating behavioral change. However, the causal effect of the distance of a law from a prevailing social norm on the effectiveness of the law has not been explored in the literature. This study experimentally investigates if a moderate law is more likely than a radical one to change unfair social norms. In this experiment, historically advantaged and disadvantaged groups of high-caste and low-caste individuals in India will be employed as subjects in the experiment. The subjects will be allowed to create their own norms within the experiment and will be exposed to either a moderate law or a radical law depending on the treatment. The results of this research has important implications for policy development and implementation as well as law enforcement.

"Dictator games" will be used as a major tool in the experiment. In a dictator game, the first player, "the dictator", decides how she wants to split her endowments between herself and another person, "the recipient". Each high-caste individual will be assigned the role of a "dictator" and low-caste individual will be assigned the role of a "recipient". A group of dictators will create norms within the experiment by discussing among themselves how each of them should divide endowments between oneself and a recipient. After the group agrees upon the appropriate amount to be sent to their matched recipients, each dictator will make a decision about how to divide her endowment between herself and a matched recipient. There will be two between-group treatment conditions: a moderate and a radical law condition. The moderate (radical) law will require the dictators to send a minimum of a low (high) amount. These laws will be accompanied with a small non-deterrent sanction. This experiment will shed light on how individuals' behavior, beliefs about others' actions and beliefs about what others consider as appropriate behavior change with norm creation and introduction of different laws.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In my doctoral dissertation I study behavioral change in developing countries and, more specifically, I study how formal rules change caste norms and behavior. 

Caste norms have been historically regressive and discriminatory towards the low castes in India. Many of these norms persist to this day. For instance, members of high castes consider the low castes to be “polluted” and exclude them from using public goods like water from public wells and places of worship. Despite laws supporting the rights of the low castes, discrimination against these people is still evident in many parts of the country.

Why do the high castes ignore rules supporting the rights of the low castes? Are these rules ineffective because they are very different from the current norms? More generaly, in a developing country context where enforcement is weak, would moderate laws perform better than radical laws? How much do individuals care about being in compliance with laws?

To answer these questions, I conducted a lab-in-the-field experiment in six villages in the state of Tamil Nadu in India. I conducted the experiment using surveys and measured individuals' economic decisions under different scenarios. I collected data by running 18 experimental sessions with a total of 603 subjects.

I use data from these sessions to study the effect of moderate vs radical rules in changing behavior and norms. I also estimate individual’s willingness to pay to be compliant with these rules.

I study sharing norms of high-caste individuals towards low-caste individuals in dictator games. Each high caste individual is given some money (200 rupees which is about $3) and asked to decide how to share the money with a low-caste individual. They play two rounds of dictator games. In the first round, there are no rules about how to share the money while in the second round, they are exposed to one of three rules treatments specifying how to share the money.  They are exposed to either a moderate rule or a radical rule or a no rule treatment. The moderate rule is send at least 30% of your money, radical rule is send at least 50% of your money and the no rule does not have any rule and is the base treatment condition. In addition to measuring sharing decisions, I measure individuals’ beliefs about social acceptability of different actions using an incentivized coordination game. 

I find that radical rules are effective in changing behavior and beliefs about social acceptability of actions but moderate rules are not as effective. Effects are heterogeneous. Less generous people respond more to moderate rules while generous people respond more to radical rules. Thus, policy makers will have to consider initial distribution of norms and behavior in the population in order to craft optimal laws.

The intellectual merit of this project is that it provides a first causal analysis of how collective beliefs and behaviors change when a formal rule (moderate or radical) is introduced in the presence of a conflicting social norm. It complements the theoretical literature that studies the efficacy of moderate and radical laws in the presence of unfair norms in developing countries. 

The broader impact of this project is that it contributes to the understanding of optimal law design. The results of this project provide inputs that can help in crafting laws that are easy to enforce for the governing body and to comply with for the citizens.
